<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 890, 89]]<|/det|>
A spacecraft is travelling in space with no resultant force and no resultant moment acting on it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 522, 120]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the spacecraft is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 129, 134, 148]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 129, 354, 148]]<|/det|>
Its direction is changing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 156, 134, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 304, 175]]<|/det|>
It is in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 133, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 348, 201]]<|/det|>
Its speed is decreasing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 208, 133, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 208, 344, 227]]<|/det|>
Its speed is increasing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 253, 94, 272]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 252, 598, 272]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 282, 361, 301]]<|/det|>
Each lift takes the same time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 312, 487, 331]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 343, 320, 361]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 375, 443, 470]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[662, 343, 683, 361]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 512, 320, 530]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 536, 443, 618]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[662, 512, 683, 530]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 555, 804, 615]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 642, 96, 660]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 641, 571, 660]]<|/det|>
Electrical energy may be obtained from nuclear fission.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 672, 576, 689]]<|/det|>
In which order is the energy transferred in this process?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 701, 133, 720]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 701, 658, 720]]<|/det|>
nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler \(\rightarrow\) turbines

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 730, 133, 747]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 730, 658, 747]]<|/det|>
nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) turbines \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 757, 133, 776]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 757, 658, 776]]<|/det|>
nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) turbines

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 785, 133, 803]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 785, 658, 803]]<|/det|>
nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler \(\rightarrow\) turbines \(\rightarrow\) generator

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A person lifts a book from floor level to a shelf. It falls to the floor and a second person lifts it back up to the shelf.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 117, 405, 134]]<|/det|>
Which statement **must** be correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 145, 133, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 144, 744, 163]]<|/det|>
The second person does the same work on the book as the first person.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 171, 131, 190]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 171, 641, 190]]<|/det|>
The second person takes the same time as the first person.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 198, 131, 217]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 198, 688, 217]]<|/det|>
The second person develops the same power as the first person.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 223, 133, 242]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 223, 920, 255]]<|/det|>
The second person does the same work on the book as the first person, develops the same power and takes the same time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 284, 106, 303]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 504, 91]]<|/det|> A liquid is evaporating. The liquid is not boiling. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 646, 120]]<|/det|> Which statement about the liquid is correct at an instant in time? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 129, 134, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 129, 626, 147]]<|/det|> Any molecule can escape, and from any part of the liquid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 156, 133, 174]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 156, 648, 174]]<|/det|> Any molecule can escape, but only from the liquid's surface. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 131, 201]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 183, 836, 201]]<|/det|> Only molecules with enough energy can escape, and only from the liquid's surface. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 209, 133, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 209, 804, 227]]<|/det|> Only molecules with enough energy can escape, but from any part of the liquid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 254, 107, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 253, 648, 272]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a sealed gas cylinder with a movable piston. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 280, 670, 440]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 450, 850, 468]]<|/det|> The piston is moved slowly downwards and there is no change in temperature of the gas. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 481, 920, 515]]<|/det|> What happens to the average distance between the gas molecules and to the pressure of the gas? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 524, 536, 687]]<|/det|>
average distance between gas moleculespressure of gas in cylinder
Adecreasesdecreases

Dincreasesincreases

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 528, 853, 546]]<|/det|>
Visible light, X-rays and microwaves are all components of the electromagnetic spectrum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 559, 490, 576]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 586, 868, 604]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 613, 920, 647]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 655, 824, 672]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 284, 88]]<|/det|> What is ultrasound? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 133, 117]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 675, 117]]<|/det|> sound waves that are so loud that they damage human hearing <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 133, 144]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 125, 630, 144]]<|/det|> sound waves that are too high-pitched for humans to hear <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 133, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 152, 623, 170]]<|/det|> sound waves that are too low-pitched for humans to hear <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 179, 133, 197]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 179, 569, 196]]<|/det|> sound waves that are too quiet for humans to hear <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 106, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 705, 241]]<|/det|> What would be the least successful method of magnetising a steel bar? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 250, 133, 268]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 250, 598, 268]]<|/det|> Insert the bar in a coil with a large direct current (d.c.). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 277, 133, 295]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 277, 798, 295]]<|/det|> Place the bar at right angles to a weak magnetic field and hit it with a hammer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 303, 133, 322]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 303, 722, 320]]<|/det|> Place the bar parallel to a strong magnetic field, heat it and let it cool. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 329, 133, 348]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 329, 396, 348]]<|/det|> Stroke the bar with a magnet. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 373, 106, 392]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 373, 636, 392]]<|/det|> An electric current in a copper wire is due to the flow of charge. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 403, 473, 421]]<|/det|> Which particles are moving along the wire? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 384, 106, 402]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 384, 779, 402]]<|/det|>
Circuit breakers and fuses are devices used to protect a circuit from overloading.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 414, 850, 432]]<|/det|>
Which statement correctly describes the difference between a circuit breaker and a fuse?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 443, 131, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 443, 769, 462]]<|/det|>
Circuit breakers can be reset if they operate but fuses need to be replaced.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 470, 131, 489]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 470, 769, 488]]<|/det|>
Circuit breakers need to be replaced if they operate but fuses can be reset.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 497, 131, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 497, 670, 515]]<|/det|>
Circuit breakers can be used in an a.c. circuit but fuses cannot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 523, 131, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 523, 670, 541]]<|/det|>
Circuit breakers cannot be used in an a.c. circuit but fuses can.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 566, 106, 584]]<|/det|>
<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 566, 755, 584]]<|/det|>
Why might it be dangerous to use an electrical appliance in damp conditions?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 594, 131, 612]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 594, 421, 612]]<|/det|>
It might lead to the fuse blowing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 621, 131, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 621, 729, 640]]<|/det|>
It might lead to the insulation on the supply cable becoming damaged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 648, 131, 666]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 648, 425, 666]]<|/det|>
It might lead to an electric shock.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 674, 133, 692]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 674, 522, 692]]<|/det|>
It might lead to the supply cable overheating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 371, 625, 390]]<|/det|>
When wiring a house, it is important to use the correct cables.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 402, 549, 421]]<|/det|>
The current ratings of four different cables are listed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 432, 547, 451]]<|/det|>
All four cables are used in series in the same circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 463, 440, 482]]<|/det|>
Which cable is most likely to overheat?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 491, 138, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 492, 180, 509]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 491, 308, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[313, 492, 358, 509]]<|/det|>
10A

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 492, 475, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 492, 527, 509]]<|/det|>
15A

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 492, 641, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[645, 492, 693, 509]]<|/det|>
30A

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 536, 106, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 536, 853, 555]]<|/det|>
A very important experiment improved scientists' understanding of the structure of matter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 567, 655, 586]]<|/det|>
The experiment involved \(\alpha\) -particles being fired at a thin, gold foil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 597, 262, 616]]<|/det|>
What happened?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 628, 134, 645]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 628, 688, 645]]<|/det|>
All the \(\alpha\) -particles were absorbed by the nuclei of the gold atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 655, 134, 673]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 655, 591, 673]]<|/det|>
All the \(\alpha\) -particles were unaffected by the gold atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 682, 131, 700]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 682, 858, 700]]<|/det|>
Some of the \(\alpha\) -particles were attracted by the neutrons in the nuclei of the gold atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 710, 133, 727]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 710, 843, 727]]<|/det|>
Some of the \(\alpha\) -particles were repelled by the protons in the nuclei of the gold atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 757, 106, 775]]<|/det|>
<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 756, 379, 775]]<|/det|>
A nuclide has the symbol \(^{23}_{11}\mathrm{Na}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 789, 598, 808]]<|/det|>
Which statement about all atoms of this nuclide is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 818, 133, 836]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 818, 455, 836]]<|/det|>
There are 11 protons in the nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 845, 133, 863]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 845, 465, 863]]<|/det|>
There are 23 neutrons in the nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 871, 133, 890]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 871, 467, 890]]<|/det|>
There are 11 electrons in the nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 897, 133, 916]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 897, 465, 916]]<|/det|>
There are 34 nucleons in the nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 455, 88]]<|/det|>
The half-life for lead-202 is 52 500 years.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 497, 119]]<|/det|>
A sample of lead-202 produces 800 counts/s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 133, 636, 149]]<|/det|>
How long will it take for the count rate to drop to 100 counts/ s?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 161, 123, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 161, 272, 178]]<|/det|>
105 000 years

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 188, 128, 205]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 188, 272, 205]]<|/det|>
157 500 years

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 214, 128, 232]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 214, 272, 231]]<|/det|>
210 000 years

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 240, 128, 257]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 240, 272, 257]]<|/det|>
420 000 years

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 285, 104, 303]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 285, 814, 303]]<|/det|>
Why is a thick shield made of lead needed to protect people from a source of \(\gamma\) -rays?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 313, 131, 331]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 313, 707, 331]]<|/det|>
Gamma radiation is strongly ionising and so is not very penetrating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 339, 131, 356]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 339, 677, 356]]<|/det|>
Gamma radiation is strongly ionising and so is very penetrating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 365, 131, 383]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 365, 698, 382]]<|/det|>
Gamma radiation is weakly ionising and so is not very penetrating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 392, 131, 409]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 392, 668, 409]]<|/det|>
Gamma radiation is weakly ionising and so is very penetrating.
